NEW YORK, Nov 19 (IFR) - Nasdaq-listed digital printing firm Kornit Digital priced an upsized US$399.5m marketed follow-on late on Thursday that saw it raise fresh capital and enabled key backer Amazon to sell more than half of its remaining stake in the company.

After two days of marketing and coming off Kornit's record third-quarter numbers earlier this month, a syndicate led by Citigroup, Barclays, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley sold 2.65m Kornit shares, about 5% of the company, at US$151, a 5.8% file-to-offer discount. The shares rebounded 6.6% early on Friday in one of the strongest post-deal performances of the week.

The offering was increased in size from 2.21m shares at launch all in the form of additional primary shares. Amazon sold about 700,000 shares as expected to raise about US$106.6m and cut its stake by more than half to 1.2%.

Kornit went public at just US$10 a share in 2015, later forging a partnership to work with Amazon that also saw it issue warrants to the e-commerce giant.

Amazon also sold part of its Kornit stake (1.7m shares on that occasion) via a US$230.4m follow-on in September 2020 that was priced at just US$56.50 per share. Shares are up 70% this year. 

Kornit plans to use the primary proceeds from the offering for potential acquisitions and general corporate purposes.

(Anthony Hughes)
